H0.text: during the great depression in the 1930s the u.s. economy experienced a. Downturn

H1.text: during the great depression in the 1930s the u.s. economy experienced a. Stagnation

H2.text: during the great depression in the 1930s the u.s. economy experienced a. Contraction

H3.text: during the great depression in the 1930s the u.s. economy experienced a. recession

A4.text: In 1933 the U.S. unemployment rate had risen to 25%, about one-third of farmers had lost their land, and 9,000 of its 25,000 banks had gone out of business.

A5.text: The American economy then took a sharp downturn, lasting for 13 months through most of 1938. Industrial production fell almost 30% within a few months and production of durable goods fell even faster.

A6.text: The economy hit bottom in the winter of 1932–1933; then came four years of growth until the recession of 1937–1938 brought back high levels of unemployment.

A7.text: By 1936, all the main economic indicators had regained the levels of the late 1920s, except for unemployment, which remained high.
